docs.lead_paragraph: Facing criticism that President Bush's tax plan is too generous to the wealthy and not responsive to the faltering economy, Republicans in Congress moved today to make tax cuts more favorable to low-income taxpayers and to get money into people's pockets quicker. The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Thomas of California, announced that he had rewritten two of the main aspects of the Bush plan to give more benefits to the less affluent. The committee is scheduled to vote on Mr. Thomas's proposals on Thursday.

headline.main: Republicans Consider Increasing Tax Cut at Low End

docs.abstract: Republicans in Congress move to make tax cuts more favorable to low-income taxpayers and to get money into people's pockets quicker, in reaction to criticism that Pres Bush's tax plan is too generous to wealthy and not responsive to faltering economy; photo (M)

byline.original: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and RICHARD W. STEVENSON

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush told thousands of cardiologists at a medical convention today that he was ready to secure passage of a patients' bill of rights this year, but warned that he would veto any of the bills now in Congress because they allowed damage awards that ''will drive up health care costs.'' In his first lengthy speech as president on patient protections, a frequent subject of debate in last year's campaign, Mr. Bush said that none of the bills contained ''reasonable caps on damage awards'' against health maintenance organizations or insurers. But he embraced creating independent review boards of doctors empowered to order an H.M.O. to provide care or access to a specialist that it has denied to a patient. Such boards are part of patient protections he signed into law in Texas four years ago, though their use has been limited by a court decision.

headline.main: Bush Backs Patients' Bill of Rights, With Caveat

docs.abstract: Pres Bush says at medical convention in Orlando, Fla, that he is ready to secure passage of patients' bill of rights this year, but warns that he would veto any of bills now in Congress because they allow damage awards that would drive up health care costs; holds that none of bills contain 'reasonable' caps on damage awards against health maintenance organizations or insurers; embraces creation of independent review boards of doctors empowered to order HMO to provide care or access to specialist that it has denied to patient (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush told thousands of cardiologists at a medical convention today that he was ready to secure passage of a patients' bill of rights this year, but warned that he would veto any of the bills now in Congress because they allowed damage...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Owens-Illinois Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its Harbor Capital Advisors money-management business to Robeco Groep of the Netherlands for $490 million to reduce debt while preparing to pay asbestos claims. Owens-Illinois, which makes glass containers, is selling units that do not fit with its packaging business as it deals with health-damage claims from people exposed to asbestos products it once made and with the $5.85 billion in debt it had as of Dec. 31. The sale of Harbor Capital, the money manager for the Owens-Illinois family of mutual funds, along with other asset sales and insurance settlements, is expected to reduce the debt by about $700 million through June, the company said.

headline.main: OWENS-ILLINOIS TO SELL ITS MONEY-MANAGEMENT UNIT

docs.lead_paragraph: After another driver rear-ended Jean Fitzgerald Hillier's pickup truck near Tampa, Fla., last year, she went to a chiropractor complaining of neck and back pain, headaches, dizziness and numbness in her arms. To try to find the cause of Mrs. Hillier's discomfort, the chiropractor sent her to a medical-imaging center for diagnostic tests. The center performed two magnetic resonance imaging, or M.R.I., exams and two computerized axial tomography, or CAT, scans and charged a total of $1,516, according to court documents. Later, insurance investigators said, another corporation with the same ownership and address as the chiropractor's clinic billed Mrs. Hillier's insurer, the Hartford Financial Services Group, $5,700 for the scans -- a 275 percent markup.

headline.main: Scanning For Dollars By Middlemen; Medical Brokers Are Cited In Auto Insurance Costs

docs.abstract: Investigators say medical brokers are behind growing number of abusive and often fraudulent charges in treatment of auto accident victims in Florida; across country, fraud and abuse in diagnostic imaging, one of most expensive and common medical procedures for auto accident victims, is major reason injury claims in several states are rising at three times rate of medical costs in general; nationwide fraud and abuse related to medical treatment for auto accident victims cost insurers about $5.4 billion a year and add average of nearly $35 to annual cost of every car insurance policy; lawsuits involving Advanced Imaging Center in Clermont, Fla, and Hartford Financial Services Group discussed; chart; photos (M)
